overview: From 2025-11-01 to 2025-12-01, ethereum-optimism/superchain-registry had 30 new PRs (25 merged), 1 new issues, and 60 active contributors.

topIssues.title: Update print_staging_report script to be dispute-game v2 compatible
topIssues.author: Inphi
topIssues.body:
The print_staging_report script is used to manually validate new chains that are added to the SCR. 
The script dumps the game args of the permissioned game by [reading them from the game implementation contract](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/superchain-registry/blob/f33efe105393d892365fda9fda42eb69951d011a/ops/internal/report/l1.go#L194). This needs to be adapted to read from the `gameArgs` storage in the DGF if they're available.

topIssues.title: ci: update `golang-validate-all` job to give summary of passes/failures
topIssues.author: bitwiseguy
topIssues.body:
Its difficult to tell which chains are passed and failed after the `golang-validate-all` ci job completes. We should modify that job to provide a summary list of all failing chains (and optionally which tests they failed) so we don't have to parse the entire circle ci job output to determine what failed. 

Optional: Ideally this summary should be given in a format that can be consumed by an OP-beat site which shows the status of all chains in the superchain

topIssues.title: investigate L2 key handover test
topIssues.author: sbvegan
topIssues.body:
<!--
Need help?
Refer to our contributing guidelines for additional information about making a good issue:
https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/.github/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

**Bug Description**

While reviewing the op-deployer docs, [we found the L2 PAO role was incorrectly set](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/commit/d8012e05618d1dfdd20bf7383371e382e85336d6). The L2 ProxyAdminOwner standard check seemed to have given a false positive when the op-deployer/OPCM because the L2 key handover should’ve failed when generating a recent testnet. Can we please investigate [testKeyHandover](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/superchain-registry/blob/689eba77586ebdcfe7a7098251d201ab68df1214/validation/key-handover_test.go#L12) and make sure its working as expected?

**Steps to Reproduce**
<!--
1. Outline the steps to reproduce the bug.
2. Be specific and detailed to help developers replicate the issue.
-->

1. Deploy a chain using op-deployer (before the bug was fixed)
2. Create the genesis file
3. Use superchain-registry for all the standard validation checks
4. Get false positive

**Expected behavior**
<!--
A clear and concise description of what you expected to happen.
-->

The L2 ProxyAdminOwner comparision to the standard L2 PAO role should fail.

**Environment Information:**
<!--
 - Operating System: [e.g. Ubuntu 20.04]
 - Package Version (or commit hash): [e.g. op-node v1.5.1, op-node c934019]
-->

**Configurations:**
<!--
Command line flags or environment variables you're using.
-->

**Logs:**
<!--
Logs and/or error messages that help illustrate the issue.
-->

**Additional context**
<!--
Add any other context about the problem here.
-->

Related issue: https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/superchain-registry/issues/470

---

⚠️ **Notice:** Issues that do not include the following sections will be subject to closure:
- Bug Description
- Steps to Reproduce
- Environment Information

Please ensure all required sections are filled out accurately to expedite the debugging process and improve issue resolution efficiency.

topIssues.title: modify the `add-chain` tool / flow to allow chains to opt in to receive hardforks
topIssues.author: geoknee
topIssues.body:
We should make it easy for chains to opt into receiving hardforks even if they are not fully standard yet, I think that will tend to increase the usage of the --network flags. At the moment, they are automatically opted in when they promote to a standard chain, but we should explicitly document that they can opt in whenever they like.

We could have a flag in the `.env` file to declare opt-in, and the `add-chain` tool checks for that and sets `superchain_time` accordingly. See https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/superchain-registry/blob/main/docs/hardfork-activation-inheritance.md

topIssues.title: encode ProxyAdminOwner exceptions for Base and Unichain
topIssues.author: tessr
topIssues.body:
The Standard Rollup Charter, as ratified, has specific exemptions for the ProxyAdminOwner for Base and Unichain. These chains can have their PAO set to a 3/3 instead of the specified 2/2.

We should make sure that these chains have exceptions encoded in the SCR validation checks that match these requirements.

topPRs.title: print-staging-report: Update to support fetching permissioned dispute game param from game args
topPRs.author: ajsutton
topPRs.body:
Updates the `print-staging-report` command to detect when dispute games have been configured using game args rather than immutables in the implementation contract and extract the parameters from the right place.

Change is made in a backwards compatible way so that the new `DisputeGameFactory.gameArgs` method is only called if the absolute prestate isn't available from the implementation contract.

fixes https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/superchain-registry/issues/1148

topPRs.title: ops: add 'just remove-chain' command
topPRs.author: bitwiseguy
topPRs.body:
Adds a new `just` recipe to remove all chain artifacts if a chain needs to be removed from the registry:
```
just remove-chain <chainId>
```

topPRs.title: ops: staging report include SystemConfig.minBaseFee
topPRs.author: bitwiseguy
topPRs.body:
# Overview

For `op-contracts/v5.0.0` and later, there is a new `SystemConfig.minBaseFee()` getter. We want to query that getter, and compare its return value to the standard range as part of the staging report.

# Related Issues
* Closes https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/superchain-registry/issues/1093

topPRs.title: validation: add op-contracts/v5.0.0 entry to standard-versions-*.toml
topPRs.author: bitwiseguy
topPRs.body: Adds entries for op-contracts/v5.0.0 in the standard-versions-*.toml files. These entries are identical to their op-contracts/v5.0.0-rc.2 counterparts

topPRs.title: UPDATE: pushing jovian timestamps out 1 week
topPRs.author: sbvegan
topPRs.body:
MAINNET

- Jovian activates on the Mainnet Superchain at jovian_time = 1764691201 # Tue 2 Dec 2025 16:00:01 UTC 
- Swell Mainnet will also activate isthmus_time = 1764648001 # Tue 2 Dec 2025 04:00:01 UTC and superchain_time = 1764691201
- Jovain activates on the Sepolia Superchain at jovian_time = 1763568001 # Wed 19 Nov 2025 16:00:01 UTC

topContributors.summary: sbvegan: Focused on critical documentation and registry updates, merging 12 PRs to support network communications and upgrades. They executed a major update to notice pages for communications in `ethereum-optimism/docs#1847` (+2155/-698 lines) and managed key details for the Jovian hard fork, including updating release information in `ethereum-optimism/docs#1852`. In addition to these direct contributions, sbvegan was an active collaborator, providing 25 code reviews. This work shows a primary focus on maintaining and improving project documentation.

devin-ai-integration: Focused on improving the quality and clarity of documentation and contract specifications for the Ethereum Optimism project. They made several impactful enhancements to the specifications, most notably by linking defined terms to their definitions in a large refactor (`specs#856`, +274/-225 lines), adding a new `SuperFaultDisputeGame` variant (`specs#852`), and cleaning up existing contract specs (`specs#853`, `specs#854`). This was complemented by a broad effort across 12 separate pull requests to fix typos and grammatical errors throughout the `ethereum-optimism/docs` repository, demonstrating a clear focus on improving overall documentation and specification quality.

ajsutton: Focused on supporting the team through collaboration this month. They contributed to project progress by providing 3 pull request reviews, which included 2 approvals. Additionally, they participated in discussions by commenting on one issue.
joshklop: No activity this month.

bitwiseguy: This month, bitwiseguy focused on maintaining the deployment tooling, with their primary contribution being the support for the `op-contracts/v5.0.0-rc.2` upgrade in the `op-deployer` (ethereum-optimism/optimism#18154). They also fixed related test timeouts in the CLI runner via PR ethereum-optimism/optimism#18179. In addition to their own changes, they actively supported the team by providing 8 code reviews. This work shows a primary focus on bug fixes and testing within the deployment process.

sebastianst: Focused on significant refactoring and modularization within the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository to improve its core architecture. They led this effort by moving fork names into a new package (#18121) and relocating package predeploys (#18145), both substantial architectural changes. Alongside this refactoring, sebastianst also fixed a configuration loading bug in the batch decoder (#18209) and actively supported the team by providing 17 code reviews.

pcw109550: Focused on node synchronization within the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository, proposing a significant Proof of Concept for a "Light CL" in `op-node` (optimism#18196). In support of this effort, they identified and created three issues related to node syncing and potential bugs (#18124, #18125, #18126). While their primary development work was on this open PR, they also actively supported the team by conducting 14 code reviews. Their code changes, which modified 34 files, were primarily focused on bug fixes and tests.
geoknee: Contributed by reviewing and approving one pull request.

maurelian: This month, maurelian focused on development tooling and new features, merging a PR to optimize the build process in `op-deployers` (ethereum-optimism/optimism#18130). They also proposed a new `DeployFeesDepositor` script (ethereum-optimism/optimism#18223) and provided significant team support by conducting 16 code reviews. Based on their code changes, their work was primarily centered on feature development and testing.

smartcontracts: Focused on improving CI processes and contributing to future design this month, merging a pull request to enhance upgrade tests in CI (ethereum-optimism/optimism#18133). They also authored a significant design document for OPCM v2 (ethereum-optimism/design-docs#353) and were highly engaged in supporting the team's work, providing 30 code reviews. Their contributions show a focus on development infrastructure, design, and team collaboration.

mds1: Focused on CI and deployment pipeline maintenance this month, merging 6 small PRs to address bugs and configuration issues. Their contributions included updating CLI flags for the op-deployer (optimism#18143) and renaming CI jobs to align with required checks (optimism#18139). In addition to their own fixes, mds1 was an active collaborator, providing 19 code reviews for teammates. This activity shows a primary focus on bug fixes and configuration changes to ensure system stability.
Inphi: No activity this month.

aliersh: Focused on repository maintenance and developer experience, merging three pull requests this month. Their most impactful contribution was a refactor in ethereum-optimism/optimism#18212 that removed a 157-line script, simplifying the codebase. They also improved repository organization by moving specifications in ethereum-optimism/specs#851 and enhanced CI guidance for developers in ethereum-optimism/optimism#18127. This work, along with 5 code reviews, demonstrates a focus on refactoring and bug fixes, with changes primarily affecting test files.

nonsense: Focused on improving the reliability and efficiency of the Optimism stack, merging four pull requests across multiple repositories. Their most impactful contributions included restricting the transaction mempool to trusted peers in `ethereum-optimism/op-geth#719` and executing a significant refactor of the `op-batcher` in `ethereum-optimism/optimism#18174`. In addition to their own code, they supported the team by providing 6 code reviews. Their work was primarily focused on feature enhancements and bug fixes, with changes distributed across both application code and tests.

Vaios0x: Focused on proposing a broad set of enhancements for the `op-node` component within the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository, opening 33 pull requests this month. The proposed work includes significant new features such as a retry system with exponential backoff (#18116), improved context and timeout management (#18118), and enhanced error handling (#18113). Additionally, Vaios0x submitted comprehensive architecture documentation (#18117) and numerous other documentation improvements, though none of this work has been merged.

They opened pull requests in `optimism` to address test flakiness (#18106, #18107) and submitted automated code generation updates to `superchain-registry` (#1137, #1138). bearpebble: Focused on improving the stability of the Optimism node this month. This work, which included corresponding test coverage, demonstrates a clear focus on bug fixing and node reliability.

CreeptoGengar: This month, CreeptoGengar focused on extending testing functionality within the Optimism ecosystem. They opened a pull request to add Jovian hard fork support to the `op-sync-tester` (ethereum-optimism/optimism#18197). The code changes for this feature, which modified 10 files, were primarily concentrated on tests.

prestwich: Contributed to documentation this month by clarifying technical details for developers. They merged a pull request in `ethereum-optimism/docs` (#1828) that updated information on sender address modification for L1 to L2 transactions. This work was focused entirely on documentation.

sashaodessa: This month, sashaodessa focused on improving network stability within the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository. They opened a pull request to fix an issue by canceling RPC calls when an HTTP client disconnects in the `op-up` utility (#18243). This work, along with a couple of pull request comments, represents their primary contribution for the period.

Antoninoo: Focused on improving development tooling this month by opening a pull request in `ethereum-optimism/specs` (#862). This PR proposes adding a GitHub Actions workflow for Pylint analysis, which involved modifying a single configuration file to enhance the project's CI process.
